msDesc.head: John Dunstable's compilation of judicial astrology, astronomy, and scientific texts

summary.seg: Cambridge, Emmanuel College, MS 70 (hereafter Emmanuel MS 70) is a compilation of scientific texts with a particular focus on astronomy and judicial astrology. The texts within Emmanuel MS 70 were, for the most part, curated and copied by the English composer John Dunstable John Dunstable (d. 1453) (d. 1453). When M. R. James examined Emmanuel MS 70 in preparation for his Catalogue of the Emmanuel College manuscripts (printed in 1904), he recorded an inscription 'Dunstaplus conscripsit hunc librum' (Dunstable copied this book) at the top of f. 1r, but does not seem to have connected the volume to the composer John Dunstable. In 2009, R. M. Thomson published an article about manuscripts connected to Dunstable and demonstrated that Emmanuel MS 70 had both belonged to Dunstable and was (mostly) written in his hand through comparison with two other surviving books - Oxford, Corpus Christi College, MS 118 , in which Dunstable wrote a copy of Boethius' De arithmetica, and Cambridge, St John's College, MS F. 25 , a now-composite volume of which Dunstable once owned ff. 74-85.

Recognition of Emmanuel MS 70 as an item largely curated and copied by Dunstable is important for our understanding of Dunstable's intellectual landscape as the volume suggests that in addition to being a talented composer, he was also a competent scribe, was deeply interested in astronomy and astrology, and was also an accomplished artist responsible for a series of figurative illustrations of constellations in one section of the volume. In Emmanuel MS 70, Bartholomew of Parma's Breviloquium de fructu totius astronomiae (ff. 80r-111v) - essentially a catalogue of the constellations - is accompanied by delicate tinted drawings that are presumably also in Dunstable's hand. All of the images are beautiful in their own way, but readers may wish to examine the illustration of the constellation Draco on f. 96v to see Dunstable's skill at using stippling and shading to suggest volume and texture, the illustration of Eridanus on f. 104v to see his treatment of drapery, and the image of Putheus on f. 108r for his ability to suggest mood and depth in his art.

Among the many and various scientific excerpts and short treatises collected in Emmanuel MS 70 are three short passages on f. 129r attributed to the Cambridge astronomer and mathematician John Holbroke John Holbroke (d. 1437). The Holbrokian passages had not been noticed prior to the preparation of this catalogue record, and are identified in Emmanuel MS 70 by citations at the end of each excerpt: 'q[uod] M[agister] J. Holbrock', 'secundum dictum M[agister] J. Holbr'', and finally 'J.H.', all on f. 129r. Holbroke was a fellow of Peterhouse from 1393, and was Master of Peterhouse from 1421 until his death in 1437. The short Holbrooke texts in Emmanuel MS 70 include a passage on the calculation of the length of the solar year, and also refer to Holbrooke's 'Tables of Cambridge' (see Nothaft (2018) for further reading on the Tables).

In addition to all of the astronomical and astrological texts, Emmanuel MS 70 also contains medical recipes towards the end of the volume, (ff. 149v-[ii] recto) in a mixture of Latin and Middle English, some in Dunstable's hand and some in the hands of other scribes.

listBibl.bibl: M. R. James, The Western manuscripts in the library of Emmanuel College. A descriptive catalogue (Cambridge, 1904), no. 70
R. M. Thomson, 'John Dunstable and His Books', The Musical Times, 150.1909 (2009), pp. 3–16

C. P. E. Nothaft, ‘John Holbroke, the Tables of Cambridge, and the “True Length of the Year”: A Forgotten Episode in Fifteenth-Century Astronomy’, Archive for History of Exact Sciences, 72.1 (2018), pp. 63–88

summary.seg:
Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures Project
Cambridge University Library

msItem.title: Note about the names of the magi in Hebrew, Greek, and Latin
msItem.textLang: Latin with brief words in Roman-transliterated Greek and Hebrew
msItem.note: In a 15th century hand. Full transcription:Nota quod nomina trium regum sunt hec ut scribit magister in historia scolastica . Hebraice ; Appelius Amerus Damascus ./ Grece ; Galgalat Malgalat Serachin . Latine ; Jaspar Balthesar Melchior ./+.

listBibl.bibl: Also printed with minor variations in transcription in James, Cat. Emm., no. 70

msItem.title: Note about the year of birth of John the Baptist (5198) according to the anno mundi reckoning of time
msItem.note: In a 15th century hand. The note states that John the Baptist was born in the 'anno mundi' (year of the world) 5198. Full transcription: Nota quod Iohannes baptista precursor domini natus fuit transactis annis ab origine mundi . quinque milibus . centum nonaginta octo et mensibus sex . Octauiano imperium mundi tenente qui secundus imperator de Romanis fuit etc.

msItem.title: Pronosticationes de eclipsi lune
msItem.author: John of Eschenden
msItem.rubric: 1v Sequitur significatio eclipsis universalis lune iuxta sentenciam Tholomei et Haly
msItem.incipit: 1v Sicut dicit Haly
msItem.explicit: 4r et hic ad praesens sufficiant pro significacione eclipsis etc
msItem.note: A date and time for the prognostication is given early in the text: anno christi 1345 . completo de undecimo .
Two tables of calculations at the bottom of f. 3v and two horoscopes for 11 December 1345 on f. 4r.
Also in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Digby 176, ff. 9r-13r.

msItem.title: De significatione coniunctionis Saturni et Martis in Cancro
msItem.author: John of Eschenden
msItem.rubric: 4v Incipit tractatus Iohannis Eschinden quondam socii aule de Merton in Oxonis . de significacione coniunccionis Saturni et Martis in Cancro que erat isto anno Christi 1357 octauo die Iunii et de significacione coniunccionis magne Saturnis et Iouis que erat anno chrsti 1365 in 30 die Oct hora 5 minuto 22
msItem.incipit: 4v Sicut dicit Ptholomeus in centilogio
msItem.explicit: 14r ad praesans sufficiant
msItem.note: Includes horoscope diagrams for 1357 (f. 5r), 1365 (f. 10v).
A note in the margin on f. 13v seems to describe a celestial event on 21 December 1382 (anno christi 1382 21 die 10bris) and mentions Hereford and Wallingford.
Also in London, British Library, MS Harley 637, ff. 129v-143v.

msItem.title: Judgement for the year 1420
msItem.author: Iohannis de Rubeis
msItem.incipit: 14v Cum sciencia astrologia est multum utilis
msItem.explicit: 21v actum Brugis in Flandria .anno.1420. die ultram decembris
msItem.finalRubric: 21v dictum in secula seculorum amen . quod d
msItem.note: 'Magister I. de Rubeis' in the upper margin of f. 14v.
Horoscope diagram for 1421 on f. 21v.

msItem.title: Note on the sighting of a comet 6 June 1456
msItem.incipit: 22r Ex precepto quorundam maiorum meorum decreui breuiter iudicare super isto cometa nouiter uiso . et faciam 5 capitula
msItem.explicit: 22r et omnes iste sunt in signo Geminorum et oriebatur dictus cometa
msItem.note: This item is written in a lighter ink in a later 15th century hand that is not that of John Dunstable.
This text refers to the sighting of a comet on 6 June 1456: 'Quod anno christi 1456 die 6 iunii hora 6 noctis'
This text is incomplete and breaks off abruptly at the end.

This text can also be found in Florence, Biblioteca Nazionale Centrale di Firenze, MS Banco Rari 30, f. 235rv, which is a manuscript associated with Paolo Toscanelli (but see Jervis, Cometary theory, esp. pp. 43-69 for a discussion of whether f. 235 in MS Banco Rari 30 is in Toscanelli's hand).

listBibl.bibl: J. L. Jervis, Cometary theory in 15th century Europe (Lancaster, 1985)

msItem.title: Mundi essentia est infinita
msItem.incipit: 22v Mundi essencia est infinita
msItem.note: Title in upper margin of f. 22v trimmed away.
This item is not in the hand of John Dunstable.
Folio 23v is blank.

msItem.title: Commentary on Alcabitius's Liber introductorius
msItem.author: John of Saxony
msItem.rubric: 24r Johannes de Saxonia in Alchibitium
msItem.incipit: 24r Uir sapiens dominabitur astris . Ptholomeus in spaientiis almagisti
msItem.explicit: 58r casuum suum etc
msItem.finalRubric: 58r Expliciunt scripta super alkabituium facta a magistro Iohanni de Saxonia . deo gracias quod dunstaple
msItem.note: Title in the upper margin of f. 24r by another hand.

msItem.title: Note on rain
msItem.rubric: 58v Nota de pluuia
msItem.incipit: 58v Si luna dat uim marti exeunti in mansione humida
msItem.explicit: 59r angelo non fuit
msItem.note: This text is similar to some of the works of Abraham Ibn Ezra, but more work is needed to establish a precise connection.

msItem.title: Invenire ingressu planetarum in signa
msItem.incipit: 59r Si uolueris habere ingressum cuiuslibet planete
msItem.explicit: 59r ingressus planete in signum quod queris

msItem.title: Astronomical note for the year 1330
msItem.incipit: 59r Anno christo 1330 . incepit primum mansio lune 25 .gradu. arietis fixi secundum tabulas ptholoei
msItem.explicit: 59r 7o libro in eleccionibus . per mansiones lune in prohemio
msItem.note: As noticed by R. M. Thomson, this text refers to 'Haly abenragelum' (Haly Abenregel).

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, 'John Dunstable and His Books', The Musical Times, 150.1909 (2009), 3–16

msItem.title: De furto
msItem.rubric: 59v De furto
msItem.incipit: 59v Locus rei amisse signatur per locum lune
msItem.explicit: 60r de ea aliquid ueritatis

msItem.title: Si uis scire in qua mansione sit luna
msItem.incipit: 60v Si uis scire in qua mansione sit luna
msItem.explicit: 61r et illa est mansio temperata
msItem.note: An addition at the end of this text in what appears to be the hand of the 'compressed scribe' who also wrote the text on f. 22r.
Three astronomical tables across ff. 60v-61r for this text.
Extracts with marginal headings in a contemporary and in a later 'italic' hand labelling excerpts as 'de questionibus' and 'de furto'

title.supplied: Table: Nomina planetarum et aspectus lune et ad eos

msItem.title: De cogitatione (Precepit Messahala)
msItem.author: Māshāʼallāh (b. ?730, d. ?815)
msItem.rubric: 64r In nomine dei pii et misericordis . incipit tractatus de cogitacione uel intencione et ... ad messa
msItem.incipit: 64r Precepit messahallach . ut constituas ascensus per gradum suum
msItem.explicit: 64v significacionibus signorum
msItem.note: Title added in upper margin by the 'italic' hand: De cogitatione uel ... queritis.
Also in London, British Library, Harley MS 13, ff. 174r-174v.

msItem.title: Libellus interpretationum siue De inuentione occultorum
msItem.author: Māshāʼallāh (b. ?730, d. ?815)
msItem.rubric: 64v In nomine libellus incipit interpretacionis quam puto esse messeallath . inveni enim eum extractum de libro suo in interrogacionibus
msItem.incipit: 64v Scito quod aspiciens id est astrologus poterit errare .4. modis
msItem.explicit: 64v-65r et ubicumque fuerit dominus hore ibi erunt res intellige
msItem.note: There is a short extract from this text on f. 68v.

msItem.title: Extracts from De occultis
msItem.author: pseudo- Dorotheus
msItem.rubric: 65r Dixit Dorothius . Cum fueris interrogatus de thesauro uel de re aliquas occulta
msItem.incipit: 65r Aspice signum .7. ab ascente
msItem.explicit: 66r a ceteris qui in arte hac minus docti erant

msItem.title: De urina non uisa
msItem.author: William the Englishman
msItem.incipit: 66v Ne uel ignorancie uel pocius inuidie redarguat mi germane qui quando apud marsilium aliquantulum mecum studuisti
msItem.explicit: 68v et ego cum aliis eum in cura habui et erat emaptoicus et ptisicus

listBibl.bibl: Edited (and this MS discussed as Ca3) with French translation in L. Moulinier-Brogi, Guillaume l’Anglais, Le Frondeur de l’uroscopie Médiévale (XIIIe Siècle): Édition Commentée et Traduction Du De Urina Non Visa, Hautes Etudes Médiévales et Modernes, 101 (Geneva, 2011)

msItem.title: Extract from the Libellus interpretationum siue De inuentione occultorum
msItem.rubric: 68v De inuencione rei occulte
msItem.incipit: 68v aspice ascendens ac dominum eius et dominum hore
msItem.explicit: 68v et ubicumque fuerit dominus hore ibi erunt res intellige
msItem.note: This item is not in the hand of John Dunstable.
There is a longer version of this text on ff. 64v-65r.

msItem.title: De significacionus septem planetarum
msItem.rubric: 69r Incipit liber Iergis de significacionibus .7. planetarum in .12. domibus
msItem.incipit: 69r Dixit Iergis . Saturnus cum fuerit in ascendente
msItem.explicit: 70v Sed cum fuerit corrupta ... saturno et nunciat finem rei periculosum et malum
msItem.finalRubric: 70v Explicit Iergis de significacionibus .7. planetarum in .12. domibus
msItem.note: This text is variously ascribed to Māshāʼallāh (Messahala), Gergis (Iergis, Jergis), and Albusmasar.

msItem.title: De proprietatibus lunae
msItem.author: Haly
msItem.rubric: 71r Tractatus Haly de proprietatibus lunae in qualibet domo
msItem.incipit: 71r Luna cum fuerit in primo domo significat principatum
msItem.explicit: 71v Sicut probat aristotiles in libro metheororum
msItem.finalRubric: 71v Explicit de collecione proprietat in lune

msItem.title: De temporibus
msItem.rubric: 72r Haly de tempore secundum quemlibet planetam in quolibet signo
msItem.incipit: 72r Saturnus in ariete sub radiis facit pluuias et radios siccaturos
msItem.explicit: 72v tranquilissimus est et bonam condicionem ostendit
msItem.finalRubric: 72v Explicit Haly de temporibus secundum disposicionem cuiuslibet planete in quolibet signo
msItem.note: This text is often attributed to Haly or Kindī (Alkindi).
Folio 73r is blank.

msItem.title: De receptione planetarum siue De interrogationibus
msItem.author: Māshāʼallāh (b. ?730, d. ?815)
msItem.rubric: 73v Judicium Messehalla super questiones cuiusdam ducis prout sequitur
msItem.incipit: 73v Interrogacio cuiusdam ducis quam proposuit rex affrice
msItem.explicit: 75r sed fixit omnes res suas fixura stellarum eius in angulis
msItem.note: Folios 75v-78r (inclusive) are blank.

msItem.title: Extracts from the Exafrenon prognosticationum temporis [Latin]
msItem.author: Richard of Wallingford
msItem.incipit: 78v Cum autem cuiusquamuis aliquem planetum uel omnes planetas ad uera loca eorum
msItem.explicit: 79v istis capituli
msItem.note: Also in Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.1.1..

listBibl.bibl: Edition of the text (not based on this MS) in J. D. North, Richard of Wallingford, 3 vols (Oxford, 1976), I.179-243

msItem.title: Breviloquium de fructu totius astronomiae
msItem.author: Bartholomew of Parma
msItem.rubric: 80r Incipit breuiloquium magistri Bartholomei nacione Permensis Bononie compilatum et confirmatum per prudentes uiros de fructis tocius astronomie ad preces domini Thedisii de Fusco anno 1286 .
msItem.incipit: 80r Scribit philosophus in primo libro methaphisice
msItem.explicit: 118v Cuius hec est forma sui aspectus in celo
msItem.finalRubric: 118v Explicit breuiloquium magistri Bartholomei nacione Permensis Bononie compilatum et confirmatum per prudentes uiros de fructuartis tocius Astronomie ad preces domini Thedisii de Fusco anno domini 1286
msItem.note: Text accompanied by half-page tinted illustrations of the constellations.

Note that the ink foliation is superseded by the pencil foliation in this text; the ink foliation is correct up to f. 90v, and thereafter (and for the rest of the volume) the pencil foliation should be followed. The ink foliation skips from f. 90 directly to f. 100, although as there does not seem to be any disruption to the text or the quire structure, this is probably an error on the part of the ink foliator.
Folio 111rv is blank.
Also in Metz, Bibliothèque-médiathèque, MS 287, ff. 280r-318v, with a similar program of illustration.

msItem.title: Chiromantia
msItem.rubric: 112r Incipit ciromantia
msItem.incipit: 112r Secantur scientie inter se quemadmodum et res ex quibus sunt
msItem.explicit: 120v linea mortis a membris generantibus et sic est finis artis cyromancie Deo gracias.
msItem.finalRubric: 120v Explicit hic Cyromancia. Deo sit honor laus et gloria quod dunst

msItem.title: Chiromantia
msItem.incipit: 121r Cum tractare uel unde cyromantia primo dicam quid sit cyromantia
msItem.explicit: 123v ex solo signo sed ex pluribus . Hec quam dicam sunt de cyromancia ad praesens sufficiantur

msItem.title: Chiromantia
msItem.incipit: 124r Si sub linea uite iuxta recepta in monte manus
msItem.explicit: 124v operacione corrigitur
msItem.note: Folios 125r-126r inclusive are blank.

msItem.title: Secreta secretorum
msItem.author: pseudo-Aristotle
msItem.rubric: 126v Incipit phizonomia aristotelis
msItem.incipit: 126v Inter ceteras sciencias hoc est quam te non oportet ignorare
msItem.explicit: 127r diuersa signa declina semper ad melius
msItem.note: This is the section on physiognomy in the Secreta secretorum.

msItem.title: De modo componendi almanach
msItem.rubric: 128r Incipit tractatus de modo componendi almanach
msItem.incipit: 128r In composicione almanach sic procede primo de sole
msItem.explicit: 128v commencionem sub hac
msItem.finalRubric: 128v Completus est tractatus de modo componendi almanach deo gratias quod d

listBibl.bibl: In eTK as 0667D (t0128910000) but seems closer to eTK 0667H
C. P. E. Nothaft, 'Ephemerides in High Medieval Europe: The Textual Evidence', Journal for the History of Astronomy, 52.1 (2021), pp. 33–52 [DOI:10.1177/0021828620981432]

msItem.title: Short note on astronomy
msItem.note: A short note on astronomy with particular reference to the planetary motion of Jupiter and Saturn.

note.p: Three short notes and some marginal calculations attributed to John Holbroke. The first note is an excerpt from Holbroke's 'Quantitas anni solaris sit' and concludes with 'quod m. J. Holbrock'. The second note is a calculation for the year 1428 and concludes with a statement that it was 'complectum secundum dictum m. J. Holbrs and was calculated according to the meridian of Cambridge. The third note includes more astronomical calculations and concludes with an attribution to 'J.H.'. The 'J. Holbrock' 'J. Holbr' and 'J. H.' here refer to John Holbroke John Holbroke , astronomer and mathematician, who was a Fellow of Peterhouse from 1393, and Master of Peterhouse from 1421 until his death in 1437.

With thanks to C. P. E. Nothaft for his confirmation of the identification of one of the passages as an excerpt from Holbroke's 'Quantitas anni solaris sit'. For more information on Holbroke see Nothaft (2018)

listBibl.bibl: C. P. E. Nothaft, ‘John Holbroke, the Tables of Cambridge, and the “True Length of the Year”: A Forgotten Episode in Fifteenth-Century Astronomy’, Archive for History of Exact Sciences, 72.1 (2018), pp. 63–88

msItem.title: De mundo
msItem.author: Abraham ibn Ezra
msItem.rubric: 129v Incipit liber Auenesre Israelite de mundo siue de reuolucion annorum mundi seu de reuolutione annorum seculi
msItem.incipit: 129v Tractatus Auenesre de planetarum coniunccionibus et annorum reuolutionibus mundanorum . Translationem aggressuri in uestibulo
msItem.explicit: 136r ad aspectus ... semper intendas
msItem.finalRubric: 136r Explicit liber de mundo et seculo completus die Iouis post festum S. Barnabe Apostoli sub ascendente scorpionis anno domini 1293 in Perside translatus autem a Magistro Henrico dicto Bate de Machelio de Hebreo in Latinum . deo gracis quod dunst
msItem.note: Translated by Henry Bate Bate, Henry .

msItem.title: Pronosticationes de eclipsi lune
msItem.author: John of Eschenden
msItem.rubric: 136v Incipiunt pronosticaciones de eclipsi uniuersali lune et de coniunccionibus 3 planetarum superiorum que apparuerunt anno domini 1345 in Marcio et complete fuerunt iste pronosticaciones 24 die predicti mensis anni predicti
msItem.incipit: 136v Significado eclipsis lune uniuersalis iuxta sententiam
msItem.explicit: 138v ad opus si ... respexisti ca que dixi
msItem.note: Contains four horoscope diagrams.
Note partially trimmed away in the upper margin of f. 137v: per m. Jo. Asshenden in ....

msItem.title: Extracts from De magnis coniunctionibus
msItem.author: Albumasar
msItem.incipit: 138v Sententia primi libri albumazaris de magis coniunctionibus
msItem.explicit: 139r prout ipse ponit in .12. ... sigillatim

msItem.title: De mercibus
msItem.author: Māshāʼallāh (b. ?730, d. ?815)
msItem.rubric: 139v Messehalla de mercibus
msItem.incipit: 139v Attende ergo ad ea que dicam
msItem.explicit: 141r utile uenditori
msItem.finalRubric: 141r Explicit liber messehale completus . deo gratias quod dunst

msItem.title: Astrological note and table
msItem.incipit: 141v Facta figura communis uel prouectionis
msItem.explicit: 141v diuiso minorato augmentato

msItem.title: Three astronomical notes in three hands
msItem.note: The first note is in Dunstable's hand, the second and third notes are each by different scribes.

msItem.title: Astronomical note
msItem.author: John of Eschenden
msItem.incipit: 142v Sicut dicit Aueroi in fine libri sui de naturalibus . initium orbis fuit ante diem Jovis
msItem.explicit: 143r et isto modo diuidiuntur orbes magni a principio mundi etc
msItem.note: The association of this text with John of Eschenden is based on the final rubric in this manuscript.
This text makes reference to the year 1345 several times.

msItem.title: Horoscope and diagram
msItem.note: The horoscope appears to be for a date in 1449.

msItem.title: Extracts from de magnis coniunctionibus
msItem.author: Albumasar
msItem.rubric: 143v Liber albumasar de coniunctionibus
msItem.incipit: 143v Nota quod tempore coniunctionis
msItem.explicit: 144r arietis quot sunt anni
msItem.note: With three tables.
Followed by a ?geometrical note in the hand of the 'compressed scribe'.

note.p: Two astronomical notes on f. 144v, one in the hand of the 'compressed scribe' and another in a scribe who added notes in three places in the volume in a very hasty cursive minuscule.
Folios 145r-149r blank except for a few signatures and a record of a debt belonging to a 'Richarde Stonnerd' on f. 147v.

Full transcription of the note on f. 149v:
Tres filii noe post diluuium diuiserunt totum orbem terrarum in .3. partes .viz. in Asiam Affricam et Europam. Sic aut dilatauerunt terminos suos , posuerunt quibus Seem . in asyam . Cam . in Affricam , Japhet in Europam , In Asya . ... sunt 15 prouinciae viz . India Achaya . Parthia . Syria . Persia . Medea . Mesopotamia . Capodocia . Palaestina . Armenia . Cecilia . Caldaea . Grecia . Egiptus et Libya . In Affrica sunt 12 prouincie Lidia . Cirini . Pentapolis . Ethiopia . Tripolitania . Bisantia . Getulia . Nathabris . Numedia . Samaria . cyrtes majores et minores. In Europa sunt 13 prouincie . Roma . Calabria . Hyspania . Alemmania . Macedonia . Dacia . Dalmatica . Pannonia . Colonia . Gallia . Acquitania . Britannia . Hybernia etc
This text is found in some copies of Nennius' Historia Brittonum - see Van Duzer and Sáenz-López Pérez for more information.

Also in
Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 139
Cambridge, University Library, MS Ff.1.27, f. 12v
Durham, Cathedral Library, MS B.II.35
London, British Library, MS Burney 310
London, British Library, MS Cotton Caligula A VIII
London, British Library, MS Royal 13.D.V
London, College of Arms, MS Arundel 30
In Middle English -
London, British Library, MS Add. 37049
Van Duzer and Sáenz-López Pérez print this text from Cambridge, University Library, MS Ff.1.27, f. 12v and discuss the major variants among seven Latin versions and one Middle English version of the text; the variant in Emmanuel College MS 70 appears to have been unknown to Van Duzer and Sáenz-López Pérez at the time of the preparation of their article. According to the Van Duzer and Sáenz-López Pérez edition, the text in Emmanuel College MS 70 is particularly close to the text in London, British Library, MS Cotton Caligula A VIII which also has Libya in Asia and Lydia ('Lidia') in Africa, and lists Rome ('Roma') against the more textually-common Italy ('Italia') in Europe.

listBibl.bibl: For a discussion of this text (but not Emmanuel College MS 70) see C. Van Duzer and S. Sáenz-López Pérez, 'Tres filii Noe diviserunt orbem post diluvium: the world map in British Library Add. MS 37049' Word & Image 26.1 (2009), pp. 21–39, https://doi.org/10.1080/02666280902846624

msItem.title: Note on weights and measures in Latin deriving from the Antidotarium Nicholai
Note on weights and measures in Middle English deriving from the Antidotarium Nicholai

note.p:
Full transcription of the note on weights and measures in Middle English on 149v:
ffor to rede and vnderstande þe wrytynge of fysicianes and lechis þat þey make in hire bookys of medicines , and hire figures ., where it be in englisshe or in latyn , ye shal vnderstonde , þat a povnde . is figured in this wyse li.j., An halfe povnde þus .li dj. or ellis þus .li ß ., and a quartron . of a povnde is þus write . quarte li. and an ovnce is þe xij part of a povnde and is þus write ℥.j. and halfe an vnce þus ℥ di or þus . ℥ ß . A dragme is þe viij parte of an vnce , and ys write þus . ʒ . j ., half a dragma is þus .ʒ.dj or þus .ʒ.ß. A scrupule is þe iij . parte of a dragme , and is þus Wri te .℈.j. A half a scripule ℈ dj . or þus ℈ ß . A scripul . Weyethe a pe ny , and a dragme .iij.d., and a vnce ij.shillinhs. a quarte of a povnde vj shillings , and half a povnde .xij. shillings , and a povnde xxiiij shillings , And an handful ys Wri te þus .m j. and half a handful þus m dj , or þus m ß . and þus þey be in boke of latyn etc

As pointed out by Voigts, there are similar texts in:
London, British Library, MS Additional 30338, f. 11r
London, British Library, MS Sloane 3171, ff. 1v-2r
London, Medical Society of, MS 131, f. 3r

listBibl.bibl: Discussed (and edited from London, British Library, MS Sloane 3171, ff. 1v-2r) in L. E. Voigts, ‘The Character of the Carecter: Ambiguous Sigils’, in Latin and Vernacular: Studies in Late-Medieval Texts and Manuscripts, ed. by A. J. Minnis, York Manuscripts Conferences: Proceedings Series, 1: Proceedings of the 1987 York Manuscripts Conference (Cambridge: Brewer, 1989), pp. 91–109, esp. p. 102, n. 38 and Table III no. 17

note.p: Several recipes in several hands (including Dunstable's) in Latin and Middle English.

A recipe on f. [ii] recto refers to a 'M. Jo. Wendouere deuonie', and Thomson has suggested that this may be the John Wendover (d. 1421) who was a Warden of Merton College Oxford c. 1387-1398, and who was also a rector of Bradnich in Devon from 1395 and prebendary of Netherayne in Chumleigh from 1417.
Note that the Middle English texts are not in IMEP 22.

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, 'John Dunstable and His Books', The Musical Times, 150.1909 (2009), pp. 3–16

support.material: Mostly paper, with a parchment flyleaf at each end of the volume.

foliation.note: Foliated in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the upper outer corner of the first recto in each quire, and in the upper outer corner of each recto ff. 88-112. The pencil foliation begins at f. 24r, and continues through the volume. The pencil foliation and the older ink foliation are in agreement until f. 90v thereafter the pencil foliation should be followed and the ink foliation should be ignored. The parchment endleaves were assigned temporary designations ff. [i] and [ii] in September 2023 during work on this item for the Curious Cures project in order to produce a functional TEI/XML record for this item; these designations are enclosed in [square brackets] in this description.

foliation.p: Foliated in ink in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the centre of the upper margin of each recto. The missing ff. 91-99 in this foliation sequence seems to be due to a counting error while foliating the manuscript rather than due to the loss of text-leaves as there is no interruption to the text or quire structure between the current ff. 90v-91r. A leaf between the ink foliation ff. 111 and 112 (the present f. 103) was not foliated in this foliation sequence.

collation.p:
Quires of 8 throughout the volume:
Quire 18-1 (1st leaf cancelled; ff. 1-7)
Quires 2-188 (ff. 8-143)
Quire 198-1 (7th leaf cancelled; ff. 144-150)

signatures.p: Medieval alphanumeric leaf signatures (a1, a2, a3, ... b1, b2, b3 etc) throughout the volume from Quires 4-19, in the lower outer corner of the rectos in the first half of each quire, many lost to trimming. The alphanumeric signatures are arranged as follows: Quires 4-11 have the signatures 'a'-'h'; Quire 12, no alphanumeric leaf signatures visible; Quires 13-19 have the designations 'k'-'q'. Quires 1-3 do not have medieval leaf designations, but contain texts copied in the hand of John Dunstable, who also wrote most of the material in Quires 4-19.
Quires are numbered in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire; these designations were probably added in the 20th century.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords present in the lower margin of the last verso of some quires, typically enclosed in a scroll frame, see e.g., f. 47v.

supportDesc.condition: The volume is in fair condition, with some marks of wear and damage; text is mostly legible, although some marginal annotations have been lost to trimming.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, frame only. Written in single column format, typically 42 lines to the page on full text pages and written below top line.

handNote.p: The majority of the text in this manuscript was written in a cursiva antiquior anglicana by the English composer John Dunstable John Dunstable (d. 1453) (d. 1453).
See R. M. Thomson, 'John Dunstable and His Books', The Musical Times, 150.1909 (2009), pp. 3–16 for further information.

Text by a 'compressed scribe' who writes a very small and compressed cursiva with secretary features on f. 22r, and who also appears to be responsible for additions in the same minute hand to ff. 52r (lower margin), 61r, 62r, and 143r and 150v-[ii] recto,
Short notes in a very hasty current cursive on ff. 22v-23r, 142r, 144v.

handDesc.handNote: Titles to texts, and marginal annotations throughout in the hand of a scribe writing a ?16th-century humanist italic, see, e.g., the title added in the upper margin of f. 24r and the annotations in the outer margins of ff. 55v-56r. This scribe also seems to be responsible for the various lists of the contents of the volume on ff. [i] verso-1r,

decoNote.p:
Anthropomorphised tinted drawings of the major constellations with the stars in red on ff. 110v as follows:
f. 89v: Aries
f. 90r: Taurus
f. 90v: Gemini (the twins labelled as 'Castor' and 'Pollux', naked and winged, Pollux holding a harp)
f. 91r: Cancer
f. 91v: Leo
f. 92r: Virgo (holding a ?wheatsheaf)
f. 92v: Libra (crowned and robed, holding a scale)
f. 93r: Scorpio
f. 93v: Sagittarius (a lion's body fused with a horse's, a man's head and arms, with bow and arrow)
f. 94r: Capricorn
f. 94v: Aquarius (a man emptying a ewer)
f. 95r: Pisces
f. 96r: Ursa major, Ursa minor, and Draco ('serpens tortuosus')
f. 96v: Draco (a draconid)
f. 97r: Hercules (nude, with sword and pelt of a lion attacking a serpent in a tree)
f. 97r: Corona
f. 97v: Serpentarius being held by a naked Ophiuchus who stands on Scorpius
f. 98r: Boetes (a figure wearing a hat and robe and holding a sickle and a spear)
f. 98v: 'Agitator' or 'Ophictus' (a figure wearing a hat and a robe and holding a spear in one hand and two rodent-like creatures in the other and standing in a chariot pulled by three horses
f. 99r: Cepheus (?Orion) (a robed figure with hands raised and wearing a sword)
f. 99v: Cassiopoeia (robed and sitting on some steps and framed by two vertical and two horizontal swords)
f. 100r: Pegasus
f. 100v: Andromeda (bearded, wearing a hat and robe, arms raised)
f. 101r: Perseus (wearing a cloak and shield and holding a sword and a bearded head of the Gorgon)
f. 101r: Triangulus
f. 101v: the Pleiades or the Seven Sisters, named in this manuscript as 'Gallina siue clocha' (seven female figures in robes with loose hair)
f. 102r: Lyra
f. 102v: Cygnus
f. 103r: quila (an eagle standing on an arrow)
f. 103v: Vultur cadens (a robed man piercing the breast of a large bird with a spear and standing on an arrow)
f. 104r: Cetus (a large fish with a nude man below and some hills and a city in the distance)
f. 104v:Eridianus (a man in a robe and crown sitting on a bench in a garden and playing a dulcimer)
f. 105r: Delphinus (a large creature with scales lying on some ?hills with a city in the distance)
f. 105v: Orion (a figure wearing plate armor and holding a sword and shield)
f. 106r: Canis
f. 106r: Lepus
f. 106v: Navis
f. 107r: Astronochus (a female centaur)
f. 107r: Demon meridianus without any stars marked (two robed figures sitting, the one on the right holds up a large oval ring)
f. 107v: Piscis magnus et minor (two fish in water, the upper one smaller, the lower one larger)
f. 108r: Putheus (five demons, some chained, surrounding a large tusked humanoid face)
f. 108v: Centaurus (a male centaur carrying a spear, a hare, a ?bear, and a censer)
f. 109r: Hydra (a large snake approaching a tree bearing a crow and an ewer on its back)
f. 109v: Cyon (or 'Antecanis')
f.110r: Equus secundus (a winged horse)
f. 110r: Tarabellum
f. 110v: Vexillum
Plain initials in red at some textual openings, e.g., ff. 1r, 80r, 128r and some minor divisions of the texts, e.g., 128r.
Paraph marks in red in some texts, e.g., f. 80r.

note.p: At the top of f. [i] verso: 'master harssedecon' (Master Archdeacon) in a 15th century hand.
Notes towards a list of the contents of the volume on ff. [i] verso-1r in the humanist hand which added titles and marginal annotations throughout the volume.
Notes towards a list of the contents of the volume on the upper half of f. 1r in the a hand which closely resembles the hand that added the ink foliation sequence.

Notes and scribbles signed by a ' Richarde Stonnerd Richard Stonard Kingele in the countie of Surrey', on f. 147v. Stonnerd is probably referring to the village of Kingsley (Kingele) in the county of Hampshire which is just two miles from the border with Surrey. Stonnerd appears to be recording a debt, i.e., 'Richarde Stonnerd Kingele in the countie of Surrey is indebted unto Ewan Monse of ..rrey'. It has not been possible to identify Stonnerd or Monse.

binding.p: Mid-17th century binding. Fully bound in leather over pulp-boards with matching decoration in blind to left and right covers. Covers are decorated with a triple-fillet frame with Oxford corners set at the perimeter of the boards. Rebacked, and original cover material over the boards has been replaced. Spine is capped at head and tail, no head and tail bands visible. Four raised bands on spine, each with a single-fillet through their centre across the width of the spine. Spine compartments are decorated with a double fillet at their upper and lower perimeters and at the upper and lower openings of the spine. Four printed paper labels fixed to the spine with an adhesive, 'MSS.', '1', '3', '18', for a former shelfmark.
Head, fore, and tail edges of the bookblock sprinkled with red.

Pastedowns have been lifted and the inner faces of the boards are exposed. The inside of the right cover is blank except for small traces of a printed paper leaf. The inside of the left cover contains the following items:
The number '70' in pencil set in a lozenge frame for the M. R. James Catalogue number of the volume
The shelfmark 'MSS 1. 3. 18' in ink and pencil
An Emmanuel College armorial bookplate by Metcalfe of Cambridge: a lion rampant in the right paw a laurel wreath with the motto "ΕΜΜΑΝΟΥΗΛ" (the Greek form of 'Emmanuel') on the escutcheon and the words 'Collegii Emmanuelis Liber' below
The endleaves ff. [i] and [ii] are former pastedowns, and both bear traces of adhesive on their outermost faces.
Dimensions (L x W x D): 200 x 150 x 45 mm.
Housed in a dark blue box with a label 'MS 70' stamped in gold and bearing a label on the inside of the box: 'This box was made using a generous donation from Colin Leach 2015'.

Evidence of two metal clasps belonging to a former binding visible on the parchment endleaves as two sets of rectangular puncture marks visible along the fore edge of the leaf, see esp. f. [ii] verso. The parchment endleaves have traces of adhesive residue consistent with having been used as pastedowns at a previous time, but the parchment leaves must have been free endleaves during the lifetime of Thomas Leigh (d. 1686) Thomas Leigh (d. 1686) , a former owner of the volume, as he was able to write his name on f. [i] recto.

origin.origDate: Written between c. 1420 and 1453, for the most part by John Dunstable (d. 1453).
origin.p: Date and location of production assigned based on the identification of the scribe as John Dunstable, whose biographical details are known. The extract from Iohannes de Rubeis on ff. 14v-21v is an astrological judgment for the year 1420.

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, 'John Dunstable and His Books', The Musical Times, 150.1909 (2009), 3–16

provenance.p: Written and owned by the English composer John Dunstable John Dunstable (d. 1453) , d. 1453, whose name appears on f. 1r, Dunstaplus conscripsit hunc librum and throughout the volume in short signatures at the end of several texts. R. M. Thomson has identified two other surviving manuscripts with Dunstable connections: Oxford, Corpus Christi College, MS 118 and Cambridge, St John's College, MS F.25 (James 162).

listBibl.bibl: R. M. Thomson, 'John Dunstable and His Books', The Musical Times, 150.1909 (2009), pp. 3–16

provenance.p: [i] verso: owned by Thomas Leigh (d. 1686) Leigh, Thomas (d. 1686) , fellow of Emmanuel c. 1657-1665. Leigh's name is also present on f. [i] recto as 'Tho. Leigh.'

acquisition.p: [i] verso: Donation inscription recording the donation of the volume in 1667 to Emmanuel College, Cambridge: 'Ex dono Tho. Leigh S. Th. Bacc. Coll. Emman. nuper Socii' by Thomas Leigh (d. 1686) Leigh, Thomas (d. 1686) , fellow of Emmanuel c. 1657-1665.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by M. R. James in The Western manuscripts in the library of Emmanuel College: A descriptive catalogue (Cambridge, 1904), no. 70 and also draws significantly on R. M. Thomson, 'John Dunstable and His Books', The Musical Times, 150.1909 (2009), pp. 3–16. Readers of this record are encouraged to consult both items for further information about this volume.

availability.p: Visitors to Emmanuel College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Emmanuel College: Special Collections.

custodialHist.custEvent: Number 39 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697)

biblStruct.note: Cambridge, Emmanuel College MS 70 is Ca3 in the edition

monogr.title: Sternbilder des Mittelalters und der Renaissance: Der gemalte Himmel zwischen Wissenschaft und Phantasie Text und Katalog
The Light Ages: A Medieval Journey of Discovery

analytic.title: Ephemerides in high medieval Europe: The textual evidence

monogr.title: Journal for the History of Astronomy

revisionDesc.change: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
